Article: SAN JOSE, Calif. â Advanced Micro Devices showed as many as two dozen systems using Epyc 7000, the server processor family it released today. The launch reignites competition in one of the most lucrative sectors of Intelâs x86 business. AMD announced nine Epyc processors, using its Zen x86 core to deliver 23â70% more performance than Intelâs 14-nm Broadwell parts across a range of benchmarks. All support eight 2,666-MHz DDR 4 channels and 128 PCI Express Gen 3 lanes, compared to about four memory channels and 40 PCIe lanes in the average Xeon. The chips arrive as Intel is about to roll out its first 14-nm Xeon chips based on its Skylake architecture. Some Epyc parts âcould still be ahead of Intelâs coming generation, but not as much,â said Nathan Brookwood, principal of market watcher Insight64. âAMDâs Epyc has a very real opportunity to disrupt Intelâs two-socket server cash machine,â said Kevin Krewell, senior analyst at Tirias Research. âIntel has controlled that market well and has been able to protect its position while slowly increasing its ASPs.â  The 14-nm Epyc chips beat 14-nm Broadwell Xeons across a range of benchmarks.
